bibl.title: Letter from Leonard Wood to the Adjutant General, December 13, 1900

div1.p: Wood explains that Cuba is largely free from epidemic or contagious diseases and he suggests that commercial relations to be resumed with the island. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Leonard Wood to the Adjutant General, December 13, 1900
div1.opener:
File
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
HEADQUARTERS
DEPARTMENT OF CUBA
HAVANA
DECEMBER 13, 1900.
The Adjutant General,
U. S. ARMY,
Washington.
Sir:
div1.p:
I desire to invite your attention to the sani-
tary situation now existing in Cuba in order that general pub-
lic opinion in the United States may be corrected. The island
is, as a whole, free from epidemic or contagious diseases at
present with the sole exception of Havana where there still
remain a few cases of yellow fever, though not enough to re-
ceive serious consideration. The total death rate from all
causes in the City of Havana for the month of November was the
lowest of any month, without regard to season, for the past
ten years. Inasmuch as apprehensions arising out of the yel-
low fever situation of the past summer still remain, it may be
advisable to give this subject general publication, in order
that full commercial and other relations with the island may be
resumed.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, Leonard Wood MAJOR GENERAL,
Commanding.
Backreturned
Dec. 21, 1900
